Based on the symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is **Nephrotic Syndrome**.

The presence of periorbital edema, proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia are the classic triad of nephrotic syndrome. This condition is characterized by damage to the glomerular filtration barrier, leading to excessive protein loss in the urine (proteinuria). The loss of protein, particularly albumin, results in decreased serum albumin levels (hypoalbuminemia). The reduced oncotic pressure from low albumin leads to fluid shifting into the interstitial space, causing edema.

The confidence level is 95.

The presence of periorbital edema, proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia are the classic triad of nephrotic syndrome. This condition is characterized by damage to the glomerular filtration barrier, leading to excessive protein loss in the urine (proteinuria). The loss of protein, particularly albumin, results in decreased serum albumin levels (hypoalbuminemia). The reduced oncotic pressure from low albumin leads to fluid shifting into the interstitial space, causing edema.
